title: The Abbasid Period and the Golden Age of Islam (750â€“1258)

text: The Abbasid period is considered one of the brightest periods of Islamic history not only politically but also in the fields of culture, science, art, and thought. This period, which lasted for about five centuries, is a multifaceted process where different nations and cultures came together to build a common civilization. For this reason, it is referred to as the "Golden Age of Islam".

content.section: 1. Moving the Capital to Baghdad and the New Center
text: With the Abbasids coming to power, the center of the Islamic world moved from Damascus to Baghdad. From the day it was founded, Baghdad became a city developing intertwined with science and culture. Being at the intersection of trade routes brought together the scientific accumulation of different societies in this city. This geographical advantage accelerated the rise of Abbasid civilization.

content.section: 2. The Rise of Science and Thought
text: The first title that comes to mind when mentioning the Golden Age is the extraordinary progress in science. The Abbasids initiated a great movement that researched, translated, and developed knowledge accumulated in different cultures.

The House of Wisdom established in Baghdad was not only a library but also one of the world's first major research centers. Works in languages such as Greek, Syriac, Persian, and Sanskrit were translated into Arabic. Thanks to these studies, fields such as mathematics, astronomy, medicine, philosophy, and engineering gained new momentum.

Dozens of thinkers raised in this period steered the history of world science. The universality of the knowledge they produced, not their identities or nationalities, came to the fore. Many fields such as algebra in mathematics, anatomy and pharmacology in medicine, and observation techniques in astronomy became systematic in this period.

content.section: c) Freedom of Thought and Different Schools
text: The Abbasid administration created an intellectual environment that allowed scientific activities to diversify. In this period, different currents of thought emerged in the fields of fiqh, kalam, philosophy, and literature. Debates often provided a diversity that encouraged production.

The Golden Age is not limited only to scientific progress. Fields such as architecture, calligraphy, urban planning, music, and literature also showed strong development. Cities like Baghdad, Basra, Kufa, Rayy, Bukhara, and Samarkand became cultural centers.
New cities were founded, and existing cities were modernized. Bridges, mosques, madrasas, and palaces represent the architecture of this period.

Arabic strengthened as the language of science and culture. A large accumulation of literature consisting of poetry, stories, and philosophical texts emerged. Many of the works penned in this period are still accepted as fundamental sources in world libraries.

The Abbasid administration had a multicultural state structure. Arabs, Persians, Turks, Berbers, Indians, and many other communities served within the state. This diversity strengthened the inclusive character of the civilization. Bureaucracy developed in governance, and the postal organization and administrative systems matured.

The Abbasid geography was at the center of trade routes extending from Asia to Europe. This situation ensured both the enrichment of cities and the acceleration of information flow. Trade, agriculture, and craft production formed the basis of the economic structure.

content.section: 6. Mongol Invasion and End of the Period (1258)
text: This bright period, which lasted as long as the rise of the Abbasids, received a heavy blow with the Mongol invasion. The fall of Baghdad in 1258 is accepted as the political end of the Golden Age. However, scientific and cultural accumulation moved to other regions and continued its influence for centuries. Therefore, even though the Abbasid period ended, the traces left by the civilization became permanent.
The Abbasid period is the most comprehensive period of cultural and scientific production in Islamic history. In this process:
-Different cultures met within a common civilization,
-Scientific and intellectual accumulation shaped world history.
For this reason, the Abbasids are accepted as the period when the "universal" character of Islamic civilization emerged most strongly.
